body:
- `nvim --version`: NVIM 0.1.4
### Actual behaviour

When doing e.g. `:map`, nvim uses the old clunky vim pager. Which cannot, for instance, _search text._ 
### Expected behaviour

Totally open - I'd be happy with `:terminal less` or putting the text-to-be-paged into a readonly temporary buffer so that I can stay in Vim interfaces.
### Steps to reproduce using `nvim -u NORC`
1. `runtime mappings.vim`
2. `:map`
3. Try to find the mapping you established years ago to bump the foldlevel
4. Despair

comment_data.body: You can do `:put =execute('map')` and search the buffer.
Maybe in master? 0.1.4 doesn't have that yet - I get "Unknown function: capture"
Maybe behave the same as with positioning cursor over some word (say `malloc`), switching to NORMAL mode and then pressing `3K`?
I think a pager will search capability would be the right approach.
I don't get the point in re-inventing the wheel. Vim is already fully-fledged editor. Pop up an RO buffer, `:only`, stick a status bar at the bottom making it clear it's a "pager", and call it a day.
I really like @mqudsi line of thinking, honestly. Not only do you get "page back" and "search" but all the rest of Vim's interface e.g. registers.

I don't think anyone disagrees :) Moved to "todo" milestone.

The pager is a relic of Vim's precious compile-time feature matrix. Even today you can build without `FEAT_WINDOWS`.

It would be useful to set neovim itself as `$PAGER`.
And would be super useful if [neovim-remote](https://github.com/mhinz/neovim-remote) can support that

I think both pager and also `:!` terminal can be solved with some inspiration from floating window:  leave the the current tabpage split layout completely untouched, and just create a window similar to a floating window, but with `wp->w_winrow, w_wincol, w_width, w_height` set to cover the entire screen, and make it modal the same way as cmdline window.
@bfredl I like floating windows, but will it break the compatibility with vim? maybe some plugins use `:map` or `:let` or `:function`.  BTW, will it break `let g:foo = execute(':map')`?

@wsdjeg any change here breaks compatibility strictly speaking (spacebar heating). It will certainly not break `execute('map')` as that explicitly sidesteps the pager. But how do mean plugins otherwise rely on the pager behavior of those commands?

> But how do mean plugins otherwise rely on the pager behavior of those commands?

sorry, I mean some plugin use `execute(':map')`, if it does not break this feature, I am ok, ðŸ‘

@I60R this issue is not about the `$PAGER` (which you use for example to view man pages from the shell). It is about a build in "pager" feature in vim/neovim which is used when a command produces a lot of text in the commandline.

Sidenote: There are at least three ways to use neovim or vim as `$PAGER`.
1. neovim (like vim) ships with the old `macros/less.{sh,vim}` files
2. https://github.com/rkitover/vimpager which is inspired by the above, very feature rich and big, also supports neovim
3. https://github.com/lucc/nvimpager which aims to be a simplification of 2. (WIP by me :)

@lucc thank you for pointing me (and others) out to these options.
I was using rkitover/vimpager in past and it was very slow on large texts because ANSI color codes concealing and highlighting was done through AnsiEsc.vim plugin. 
Concealed characters also can be yanked and obstruct navigation.

-----------
Here is my attempt:
https://github.com/I60R/page
It uses terminal buffer, so all is fast and smooth

@justinmk can you take a brief look at the link I posted above and say me if similar functionality can be provided with neovim natively?
Does it make sense to not announce my program now to preserve potential users from transition in future?

It's possible, because the terminal is mostly decoupled from channels/PTY. It wouldn't be too much work to add the ability to create a quasi-:terminal that displays data fed from api function, rather than a PTY. I would use this in nvim-ipy rather than implementing ansi colors + `^H` + `^M` as I do now... (edit 2021:  `nvim_open_term` )
Came here looking for the same functionality: being able to search in VIMs internal pager. I know there are workarounds, but it would be great if this was supported out of the box.

Are there currently any workarounds that would allow us to intercept any commands that cause that the built in pager to be activated and redirect stuff to a buffer? 

I'm currently using a plugin called https://github.com/AndrewRadev/bufferize.vim that allows you to do `:Bufferize SearchUnicode arrow` or `:Bufferize map` to put everything in a buffer, but you lose any highlighting, and you need to remember which commands to manually prefix with `:Bufferize`.

> You can do `:put =capture('map')` and search the buffer.
> 
> Note: `capture()` will be renamed to `execute()` since Vim added that function recently.

Thanks to this hint, I use the following crude script to get my job done. (I wish I could find a way to show the output of `:highlight` with its color and text style in the buffer)

```vim
" capture (dump) the (somewhat long) ouput of the commands like `:digraph`, `:map', `:highlight`, `:scripnames` etc.

function! s:dump(cmd) abort

    " Start a new split or maybe a buffer or a tab
    " enew | " open a new buffer
    10split | enew | " open a new split (with 10% height (?))
    " tabnew | " open a new tab

    " Make it a scratch buffer ( `:help special-buffers`)
    setlocal
                \ bufhidden=wipe
                \ buftype=nofile
                \ nobuflisted
                \ nolist
                \ noswapfile
                \ norelativenumber
                \ nonumber

    " Write the cmd output to the buffer
    put =execute(a:cmd)
    " There are 2 empty line at the beginning of the buffer before the ouput of
    " the cmd. Not sure from where they are comning from. Anyhow I will delete
    " them.
    norm gg2dd

    " No modifications to this buffer
    setlocal readonly nomodifiable nomodified

    " Press escape to close when you're done
    nnoremap <buffer><silent> <Esc> :bd<CR>

endfunction

" Define a command to use the function easier
command! -nargs=1 Dump execute "call s:dump(" string(<q-args>) ")"
```

> Thanks to this hint, I use the following crude script to get my job done. (I wish I could find a way to show the output of `:highlight` with its color and text style in the buffer)

I use [this script](https://github.com/gpanders/dotfiles/blob/master/.config/nvim/autoload/scratch.vim) script to add highlights to scratch buffers based on some simple heuristics (with [these commands](https://github.com/gpanders/dotfiles/blob/master/.config/nvim/plugin/scratch.vim)). With this you can just use `:Highlight`.

Since https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27855 was merged in Nvim 0.12, you can try:

    require('vim._extui').enable({})

then the pager is now a real buffer/window.

title: Replace the builtin pager

type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality
type.name: Enhancement
